<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 252, 698, 271]]<|/det|>
He then plots the data against time for different sections of his journey.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 282, 700, 301]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 71, 910, 89]]<|/det|> Two stones of different weights fall at the same time from a table. Air resistance may be ignored. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 346, 120]]<|/det|> What will happen and why? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 930, 260]]<|/det|>
what will happenwhy
ABoth stones hit the floor at the same time.Acceleration of free fall is constant.
BBoth stones hit the floor at the same time.They fall at constant speed.
CThe heavier stone hits the floor first.Acceleration increases with weight.
DThe heavier stone hits the floor first.Speed increases with weight.
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 286, 97, 304]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 286, 853, 304]]<|/det|> Diagram 1 shows a sealed plastic bottle containing a hollow glass sphere and a steel ball. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 317, 603, 335]]<|/det|> Diagram 2 shows the same bottle after it has been shaken. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 348, 920, 381]]<|/det|> Diagram 3 shows the same bottle after it has been shaken again until the broken glass is in tiny pieces. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 393, 925, 549]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 559, 574, 577]]<|/det|> The mass of the bottle and contents in diagram 1 is \(m_{1}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 590, 574, 607]]<|/det|> The mass of the bottle and contents in diagram 2 is \(m_{2}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 619, 574, 636]]<|/det|> The mass of the bottle and contents in diagram 3 is \(m_{3}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 649, 675, 666]]<|/det|> Which statement gives the correct relation between \(m_{1}\), \(m_{2}\) and \(m_{3}\)? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 677, 133, 694]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 677, 480, 694]]<|/det|> \(m_{1}\) is equal to \(m_{2}\) and \(m_{2}\) is equal to \(m_{3}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 704, 133, 722]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 704, 547, 722]]<|/det|> \(m_{1}\) is greater than \(m_{2}\) and \(m_{2}\) is greater than \(m_{3}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 732, 133, 749]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 732, 520, 749]]<|/det|> \(m_{1}\) is less than \(m_{2}\) and \(m_{2}\) is greater than \(m_{3}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 758, 133, 776]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 758, 495, 776]]<|/det|> \(m_{1}\) is less than \(m_{2}\) and \(m_{2}\) is less than \(m_{3}\).

<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 584, 91]]<|/det|>
A toy car travels down a sloping ramp at constant speed.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[299, 100, 757, 230]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 240, 628, 259]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the forces acting on the car is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 269, 134, 287]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 269, 541, 288]]<|/det|>
There are no forces acting on the car vertically.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 295, 134, 314]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 295, 520, 314]]<|/det|>
There is no resultant force acting on the car.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 322, 134, 341]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 322, 544, 341]]<|/det|>
There is no gravitational force acting on the car.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 348, 134, 367]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 348, 515, 367]]<|/det|>

The box does not move because an object is in the way. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 147, 480, 164]]<|/det|> Man Y lifts box Q from the floor onto a shelf. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 173, 902, 349]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 363, 808, 381]]<|/det|> Which man does the most work on their box, and which box gains the most energy? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 393, 452, 540]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 109, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>13</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 71, 526, 89]]<|/det|>
The diagrams show three containers, P, Q and R.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[225, 98, 771, 250]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 260, 452, 279]]<|/det|>
Each container contains the same liquid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 291, 554, 310]]<|/det|>
The depth of the liquid is the same in each container.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 322, 855, 339]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the pressure of the liquid at the bottom of the container is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 350, 134, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 350, 594, 368]]<|/det|>
The pressure of the liquid at the base of P is greatest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 377, 134, 395]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 377, 596, 395]]<|/det|>
The pressure of the liquid at the base of Q is greatest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 403, 133, 421]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 403, 596, 421]]<|/det|>
The pressure of the liquid at the base of R is greatest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 429, 133, 448]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 429, 712, 447]]<|/det|>
The pressures of the liquid at the bases of P, Q and R are the same.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 472, 104, 491]]<|/det|>
<label>14</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 472, 920, 505]]<|/det|>
A person taking a shower notices that water appears on the inside of the bathroom window, even though the window is some distance from the shower.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 516, 477, 535]]<|/det|>
Which statement explains this observation?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 546, 133, 564]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 546, 819, 564]]<|/det|>
Droplets of water from the hot shower move through the air and onto the window.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 573, 131, 592]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 573, 700, 592]]<|/det|>
The colder window causes the steam in the atmosphere to solidify.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 600, 131, 618]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 600, 737, 618]]<|/det|>
Water vapour from the atmosphere condenses onto the colder window.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 626, 133, 644]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 626, 490, 644]]<|/det|>
The hot water boils and turns into steam.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 107, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 803, 89]]<|/det|> Very small pollen grains are suspended in water. A bright light shines from the side. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 101, 920, 135]]<|/det|> When looked at through a microscope, small specks of light are seen to be moving in a random, jerky manner. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[336, 144, 660, 448]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 463, 425, 481]]<|/det|> What are the moving specks of light? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 491, 134, 509]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 491, 520, 509]]<|/det|> pollen grains being hit by other pollen grains <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 518, 133, 536]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 518, 500, 536]]<|/det|> pollen grains being hit by water molecules <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 545, 131, 562]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 545, 576, 562]]<|/det|> water molecules being hit by other water molecules <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 571, 133, 588]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 571, 500, 588]]<|/det|> water molecules being hit by pollen grains <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 615, 106, 631]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 615, 381, 631]]<|/det|> A hole is drilled in a metal plate. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 644, 915, 661]]<|/det|> What happens to the length of the plate and to the diameter of the hole when the plate is cooled? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 673, 510, 802]]<|/det|>
length of platediameter of hole
Adecreasesdecreases
Bdecreasesincreases
Cincreasesdecreases
Dincreasesincreases

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 107, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 571, 89]]<|/det|> A liquid-in-glass thermometer uses alcohol as its liquid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 636, 120]]<|/det|> Which property of alcohol is used to measure the temperature? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 131, 128, 148]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 131, 256, 148]]<|/det|> boiling point <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 158, 128, 176]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 158, 207, 175]]<|/det|> colour <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 184, 128, 202]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 183, 291, 200]]<|/det|> thermal capacity <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 210, 128, 227]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 210, 215, 227]]<|/det|> volume <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 254, 107, 272]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 254, 640, 272]]<|/det|> The thermal capacity of object Y is greater than that of object Z. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 284, 378, 301]]<|/det|> What is a consequence of this? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 312, 131, 330]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 312, 640, 330]]<|/det|> Object Y needs less thermal energy to melt it than object Z. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 339, 131, 357]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 339, 824, 356]]<|/det|> Object Y needs less thermal energy to raise its temperature by \(1^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) than object Z. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 365, 131, 384]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 365, 650, 383]]<|/det|> Object Y needs more thermal energy to melt it than object Z. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 393, 131, 411]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 393, 834, 410]]<|/det|> Object Y needs more thermal energy to raise its temperature by \(1^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) than object Z. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 435, 106, 454]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 435, 905, 454]]<|/det|> The table gives some examples of convection and an explanation of why the convection occurs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 466, 297, 483]]<|/det|> Which row is correct? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 495, 910, 683]]<|/det|>
exampleexplanation
Aair conditioner unitThe unit is placed in a high position to circulate the cold air rising from the floor level and so keeping the room cold.
Bconvection ovenThe air in the oven becomes more dense when heated so it falls to the bottom heating the food faster.
Chot-air balloonAir inside the balloon becomes less dense which causes the balloon to rise.
Dland and sea breezesA breeze forms due to the warm air above the land moving down towards the sea.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 107, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 390, 89]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a d.c. motor. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[265, 98, 727, 327]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 338, 712, 357]]<|/det|> Which two changes together will always make the coil spin more slowly? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 367, 134, 384]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 367, 700, 384]]<|/det|> Decrease the current in the coil and use a magnet of less strength. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 394, 131, 412]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 394, 784, 412]]<|/det|> Decrease the current in the coil and increase the number of turns on the coil. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 421, 131, 439]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 421, 692, 439]]<|/det|> Increase the current in the coil and use a magnet of less strength. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 448, 131, 465]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 448, 781, 465]]<|/det|> Increase the current in the coil and decrease the number of turns on the coil. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 490, 104, 508]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 490, 351, 508]]<|/det|> The charge on a proton is \(e\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 520, 707, 538]]<|/det|> What is the charge on an electron and what is the charge on a neutron? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 549, 416, 680]]<|/det|>
electronneutron
Aee
Be0
C\(-e\)\(-e\)
D\(-e\)0
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 705, 104, 724]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 705, 695, 724]]<|/det|> The proton numbers and nucleon numbers of four nuclides are shown. <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 734, 714, 764]]<|/det|> \[^{231}_{88}\mathrm {Ra}\qquad ^{232}_{90}\mathrm {Th}\qquad ^{238}_{92}\mathrm {U}\qquad ^{239}_{94}\mathrm {Pu}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 778, 348, 797]]<|/det|> Which statement is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 808, 131, 826]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 808, 641, 826]]<|/det|> Plutonium (Pu) contains one more proton then uranium (U). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 835, 131, 853]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 835, 636, 853]]<|/det|> Thorium (Th) contains one more neutron than radium (Ra). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 861, 131, 880]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 861, 626, 880]]<|/det|> Thorium (Th) contains one more proton than radium (Ra). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 887, 131, 905]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 887, 655, 905]]<|/det|> Uranium (U) contains one more neutron than plutonium (Pu).

what decayswhat happens to the atom
Athe nucleus of the atomit becomes a different element
Bthe nucleus of the atomit becomes a lighter version of the same element
Cthe outer layers of the atomit becomes a different element
Dthe outer layers of the atomit becomes a lighter version of the same element
